General information.Content: This database contains data from international key comparisons for radionuclide metrology since the inception of the international system of reference (SIR) for radionuclide metrology at the BIPM in 1976.

References.[1]: Romain Coulon et al 2022 Meas. Sci. Technol. 33 024003 - https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6501/ac3fc4

Key comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88(2004).Reference of the published comparison re: Ratel G., Michotte C., Hino Y., BIPM comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88 of activity measurements of the radionuclide $^{88}$Y and links for the 2000 regional comparison APMP.RI(II)-K2.Y-88, \href{https://doi.org/10.1088/0026-1394/41/1A/06010}{\textit{Metrologia}, 2004, \textbf{41}, Tech. Suppl., 06010}

Key comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88(2011).Reference of the published comparison re: Michotte C., Courte S., Ratel G., Kossert K. and N\"{a}hle O., Update of the ongoing comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88 to include recent activity measurements of the radionuclide $^{88}$Y by the PTB, Germany, \href{https://doi.org/10.1088/0026-1394/48/1A/06006}{\textit{Metrologia}, 2011, \textbf{48}, Tech. Suppl., 06006}

Key comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88(2022).Reference of the published comparison re: Michotte C., Courte S., Coulon R., Nonis M., Judge S., Ratel G., Maringer F.J., Brettner-Messler R., Fr\'echou C., Bobin C., Update of the comparison BIPM.RI(II)-K1.Y-88 of activity measurements of the radionuclide $^{88}$Y to include the 2016 result of the LNE-LNHB (France) and the 2019 result of the BEV (Austria), \href{https://doi.org/10.1088/0026-1394/60/1A/06003}{\textit{Metrologia}, 2023, \textbf{60}, Tech. Suppl., 06003}

Linked comparison APMP.RI(II)-K2.Y-88(20.Reference of the linked comparison: Hino Y., Results from APMP comparisons on radioactivity measurements of $^{58}$Co, $^{88}$Y and $^{166m}$Ho, \href{https://doi.org/10.1016/S0969-8043(01)00225-1}{\textit{Applied Radiation and Isotopes}, 2002, \textbf{56}:1-2, 421-427}

Data from LNE-LNHB-2016.Description of the measurement method(s): 4pi PC x-gamma anti-coincidence, 4pi NaI(Tl) gamma counting
Data from LNE-LNHB-2016.Comment(s) on the measurement method(s): For the $4\pi\gamma$ counting method, the detection efficiency was evaluated as 92 % by Monte-Carlo simulation \cite{Thiam C., Bobin C., Maringer F.J., Peyres V. and Pommé S., Assessment of the uncertainty budget associated with $4\pi$ $\gamma$ counting, \textit{Metrologia}, 2015, \textbf{52}, S97}.
